title: Why is my AP Language teacher forcing us to write mini essays on every source we use for our term paper? - Quora

response.answer_text: Hi, Sagan. I’m flattered by your question. Before we get to your question: looking at your little photo: is that a selfie or what? Just kidding. Okay, your question. I am at a bit of a disadvantage. I tried to read your AP Language teacher’s mind, but she /he did not come through clearly. So, I’m afraid, between the two of us we shall have to figure it out for ourselves. I don’t really know where to begin, but in this modern day and age I’ve heard it said that that is no excuse. So, we’re left to ourselves. First of all, I must confess, I don’t really know what an AP Language class is. (I presume it is a class, because your teacher has the authority to make you do something you don’t understand and further, I presume again, you don’t like, because why else would you ask this question. Only jailers and teachers possess those kind of authority.) Okay, we now know it is a class. I’m not necessary as dumb as the ‘Dumb Blond’ for not knowing, but I am from South Africa and we do not have AP Languages out here. So, we’ve overcome that obstacle to reason this out. Right? Next. Let’s find the next clue. Your teacher makes you write mini essays. Another new one. I’ve never heard of mini essays. I one hundred percent know what an essay is. I can give you a lecture on that, you know. I’m really good at it, me being a writer of sorts. A mini essay sounds like a little essay, but I’ve never heard of that, as well. So, let’s try a synonym. You know what as synonym is, don’t you? I can’t see you, so I assume again that you are not a hundred per cent sure. A synonym is a different word with more or less the same meaning. This is where a synonym comes in handy. One that comes to mind is your ‘mini’. So, I would say ‘little’ says it is a ‘mini’ essay. After all that grammar, all you need to know is that no matter whether an essay is a ‘mini’ or a long essay. It is still an essay. Essay is an essay and that you know well. Seeing that this teacher makes you write essays all the time. Why? Because, seeing that AP refers to a language it seems to me that it is an essay in a language. So, now, I am not a genius so I looked up what this AP Language is. I found that it is an AP English Language and Composition course. I also read that ‘The AP English Language and Composition course is designed to help you become a skilled reader of a variety of texts as well as becoming a skilled writer. ... Using research materials and synthesizing information from various sources are integral parts of the AP English Language and Composition course.’ That, my friend speaks for itself. It is part of educating yourself. (See between the lines why) I’m sure there are a few other courses that you easily hate as much as, well, maybe not as much, as writing mini essays. Still, you have to do them for some or other reason you will not know unless your teacher tells you what the reason is. My heart goes out to you. I once were where you are now in your life. You know what? I survived. Who knows possibly you can get hooked on writing. Give it a go. I did. Go well, my friend. Don’t give up you wouldn’t like to be a loser. Write those darn essays. I’d love to take a photo of you when you win some prize for writing something. Bye for now.

I wouldn’t want to second-guess your AP teacher but I can think of a couple of possibilities. One is to give you more practice at writing. And the second is more important. In today’s world a lot of people don’t take in information critically. In other words, they trust that everything they read or hear is accurate. By asking you to write a mini-essay on your sources, I would imagine your teacher is trying to assess both your research skills (are you using primary sources that are reliable?) and your ability to synthesize information correctly. As an example, years ago in a history class I read a text on witchcraft. The author was a historian who wrote for the popular market. I read the bibliography and checked one of the source books she’d used. She had pulled some information from the primary source out of context and it changed the meaning. That was the last book I ever read from that author. And after having spent more than 20 years in mainstream print media, I hammered into my reporters to check their sources. We could only run facts and information that was a matter of public record, but could ask some witnesses what they saw or heard, first hand. Always check sources on things you read or hear.
